title: Low-risk screening due (24–28 weeks)
description: If low-risk and gestational age is between 24 and 28 weeks and no screening result exists, screening is due.
recommendation: Order a 75 g 2-hour OGTT for GDM screening (typical 24–28 weeks).

title: Screening overdue (>28 weeks, no result)
description: If GA is > 28 weeks and no screening result exists, screening is overdue.
recommendation: Screen as soon as possible (document delay). Typical test: 75 g 2-hour OGTT.

title: Postpartum OGTT due (4–12 weeks after delivery)
description: If prior GDM and postpartum age is 4–12 weeks and postpartum OGTT not done, it's due.
recommendation: Perform a 75 g 2-hour OGTT at 4–12 weeks postpartum.

title: Long-term diabetes rescreening plan (every 1–3 years)
description: If postpartum OGTT normal but no plan exists, recommend periodic screening.
recommendation: If initial postpartum test is normal, schedule ongoing diabetes screening every 1–3 years (per guideline/risk).

title: High-risk early screening due (<24 weeks)
description: If high-risk and GA < 24 weeks and no early screening result exists, early screening is due.
recommendation: Order early GDM screening (e.g., fasting glucose or HbA1c) for high-risk patients before 24 weeks.

title: High-risk early screening overdue (<24 weeks)
description: If high-risk and GA < 24 weeks and no early screening result exists, early screening is overdue.
recommendation: Order early GDM screening immediately (document delay).

title: Prior GDM, no postpartum screening plan
description: If history of GDM and no postpartum screening plan exists, recommend creating a plan.
recommendation: For patients with a history of GDM, establish a postpartum diabetes screening plan (e.g., schedule postpartum OGTT, set reminders).

title: Postpartum OGTT overdue (4–12 weeks after delivery)
description: If prior GDM and postpartum age is 4–12 weeks and postpartum OGTT not done, it's overdue.
recommendation: Perform a 75 g 2-hour OGTT immediately (document delay).
